items.summary: U.S. District Court Judge Abdul K. Kallon sentenced Scientic Inc., a Huntsville defense contractor to three years' probation and ordered the company to repay $250,000 on criminal charges of falsely obtaining Small Business Innovation Research contracts with the Department of Defense and NASA.  In addition, the company was fined $30,000.

items.title: Former Supervisor at Portland, Oregon-Area Manufacturing Company Pleads Guilty for Role in Fraud Scheme
items.summary: Dennis Balius, a former supervisor at an aluminum extrusion manufacturing company, pled guilty in the U.S. District Court for Oregon to one count of mail fraud.  As part of his plea, Balius admitted to his role in a decade-long scheme in which workers altered test results for aluminum extrusions over 4,000 times, enabling the company to gross over $6.8 million in total sales based on the false results.

items.title: NASA's Compliance with the Improper Payments Information Act for Fiscal Year 2016
items.summary: Our overall objective in this review was to determine whether NASA complied with the requirements of IPIA in fiscal year 2016. We also evaluated the completeness and accuracy of the Agency's IPIA reporting and its implementation of recommendations made in our prior IPIA reports. To conduct this review, we examined applicable laws and regulations, interviewed Agency personnel, and reviewed NASA's Agency Financial Report and supporting documentation.

items.title: District Man Sentenced for Trafficking in Counterfeit Goods
items.summary: Arthur Chan, a NASA employee, was sentenced to nine months of home confinement and ordered to perform 180 hours of community service. In January 2017, Chan pled guilty in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to trafficking in counterfeit goods. An Office of Inspector General investigation found that Chan used his NASA computer to facilitate a counterfeit apparel sales scheme.

items.summary: The Office of Inspector General (OIG) evaluated NASA's Earth Venture Suborbital (EVS) investigations to assess whether they were meeting science objectives, adhering to established cost caps, and using the most appropriate platform to perform their research.

items.name: PR-2017-D
items.title: Former NASA Employee Sentenced to Serve Ten Years in Federal Prison for Coercion of a Minor
items.summary: Thomas de Matteis, a former NASA employee, was sentenced to serve 10 years in federal prison for coercing or enticing a minor to engage in sexual activity.

items.name: PR-2017-C
items.title: Sierra Nevada Corporation Pays $14.9m to Settle Allegations of Improper Contract Billings
items.summary: Sierra Nevada Corporation paid $14.9 million to resolve allegations the company violated the False Claims Act by knowingly misclassifying defense and space contract costs, thereby overcharging federal agencies for products and services.

items.summary: The Office of Inspector General examined NASA's management of its next robotic rover mission to the Martian surface, the $2.4 billion Mars 2020 Project.

items.summary: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Authorization Act of 2000 directs the NASA Office of Inspector General (OIG) to annually assess the Agency's compliance with Federal export control laws and reporting requirements regarding cooperative agreements between NASA and China or any Chinese company.

items.name: PR-2017-B
items.title: District Man Pleads Guilty to Federal Charge For Trafficking in Counterfeit Goods
items.summary: Arthur Chan, a former NASA employee, pled guilty in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to trafficking in counterfeit goods. Chan completed approximately 610 sales of counterfeit designer apparel and accessories via his personal eBay accounts.

CLA performed the audit in accordance with the Government Accountability Office's Government Auditing Standards and the Office of Management and Budget's Bulletin No. 15-02, "Audit Requirements for Federal Financial Statements."

items.name: IG-17-002
items.title: Federal Information Security Modernization Act: Fiscal Year 2016 Evaluation (Summary)
items.summary: This annual report, submitted as a memorandum from the Inspector General to the NASA Administrator, provides the Office of Inspector General's (OIG) independent assessment of NASA's information security posture, as required by the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA). The law identifies specific security requirements Federal agencies must satisfy and assigns responsibilities to agency officials for addressing and Inspectors General for assessing these requirements.

items.name: PR-2017-A
items.title: Former NASA Employee Pleads Guilty to Making False Statements Concerning His Interactions with Contractors
items.summary: Nathaniel Wright, a former NASA employee, pled guilty to making false statements in connection with a NASA Office of Inspector General (OIG) investigation into his interactions with contractors. During the OIG investigation, Wright made false statements about providing his resume to a contractor under his purview and pressing another contractor to use his friend's business to perform work on a specific task order.

items.name: SR-2011-SHUTTLE
items.title: Review of NASA's Selection of Display Locations for the Space Shuttle Orbiters
items.summary: NASA Inspector General Paul K. Martin today released a report that examines NASA's process for choosing permanent display locations for the retired Space Shuttle Orbiters. The review found that although Agency staff made several errors during the evaluation process of prospective Orbiter recipients, NASA complied with federal law and was not improperly influenced by political considerations when it chose the Smithsonian and sites in Los Angeles, New York City, and at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

items.name: IG-11-022
items.title: NASA's Challenges Certifying and Acquiring Commercial Crew Transportation Services
items.summary: NASA Inspector General Paul K. Martin today released a report that examined the significant challenges NASA must address as it seeks to acquire transportation services from commercial companies to carry astronauts to the International Space Station and low Earth orbit. These challenges include selecting the optimal acquisition strategy, modifying existing human-rating requirements to make them applicable to commercially developed systems, and establishing the appropriate insight/oversight model for commercial partner vehicle development.
